form.official-title: To establish a commission to promote information and media literacy, and for other purposes.

subsection.text: This Act may be cited as the Educating Against Misinformation and Disinformation Act.

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 1. Short title; table of contents.
Title I—Commission to Support Information and Media Literacy and Address Misinformation and Disinformation
Sec. 105. National strategy for information and media literacy and preventing misinformation and disinformation.
Sec. 201. Grants to improve the American public’s information and media literacy and resilience to misinformation and disinformation.
Sec. 202. Study and report on information and media literacy among the American public.

paragraph.text: The term appropriate congressional committees means—

subparagraph.text: the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions and the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation of the Senate; and
the Committee on Education and Labor and the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology of the House of Representatives.

paragraph.text: The terms elementary school, local educational agency, secondary school, and State educational agency have the meanings given those terms in the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7801 et seq.).

The term information literacy means the integrated set of skills, knowledge, practices, and dispositions that prepares individuals to discover, interpret, and create information ethically while gaining a critical understanding of how information systems interact to produce and circulate news, information and knowledge (including digital information such as website and social media content).
The term institution of higher education has the meaning given that term in section 101 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1001).

The term media literacy means the ability to access, analyze, evaluate, and participate in the creation and circulation of media messages regardless of format, including learning the skills and dispositions to seek out, critically evaluate, and create media messages and understand the role of media and algorithmic information systems in society.

The term social media means forms of interactive, internet-based applications (such as websites for social networking and microblogging) through which users create online communities to share information, ideas, personal messages, and other content (such as videos).
The term State higher education agency has the meaning given that term in section 103 of the Higher Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 1003).

title.header: Commission to Support Information and Media Literacy and Address Misinformation and Disinformation

subsection.text: There is established a commission to be known as the Commission to Support Information and Media Literacy and Prevent Misinformation and Disinformation (referred to in this Act as the Commission).
The duties of the Commission are as follows:

paragraph.text: Identify and assess programs and interdisciplinary resources relating to information and media literacy in elementary, secondary, higher education, and adult education programs, including by—

subparagraph.text: identifying and assessing programs and other educational materials made available by the Federal Government;
developing metrics to report on the status of information and media literacy education in elementary, secondary, higher, and public informal education;
requesting that the Public Library Survey of the Institute of Museum and Library Services continue to collect such data on an ongoing basis; and
annually reporting on the status of such efforts.

paragraph.text: Develop and regularly update, not less frequently than annually, a national strategy to promote information and media literacy in accordance with section 105 and coordinate the implementation of such strategy.
Report on how information on the internet and social media is created and consumed, with a particular focus on how disinformation and misinformation are spread.
Develop age-appropriate materials to promote information and media literacy and education with a particular focus on misinformation and disinformation and disseminate such materials to the public.
Assess and report on strategies and techniques to help students and the public at large judge the trustworthiness and reliability of information and images.

Promote information and media literacy and related educational efforts and materials at the State and local levels, including by promoting partnerships among Federal, State, and local governments and nonprofit organizations with recognized expertise in media literacy. These efforts include misinformation and disinformation educational and media literacy campaigns for the public.
Make recommendations to the appropriate congressional committees and the Secretary of Education.

subsection.text: In carrying out the duties specified in subsection (b), the Commission shall seek to—

paragraph.text: increase public awareness of and education on—

subparagraph.text: how to find and identify if information is from a trustworthy source;
how to craft arguments, when claims are supported by evidence, and how to analyze the validity of claims and strength of arguments being made;
methods to understand the difference between fact or opinion or a mixture thereof;
methods to identify misinformation and disinformation;
how to find and evaluate context for information from different sources;
how to detect manipulation of images or information on digital platforms; and
how influencers and various organizations target and manipulate audiences through digital platforms;

paragraph.text: improve information and media literacy and education by encouraging individuals to develop related skills, including—

subparagraph.text: critical thinking skills, including how to identify the difference between credible and noncredible claims and information;
awareness of the impact of disinformation and misinformation on individuals and society;
increased familiarity and facility with new and digital media with a particular emphasis on techniques individuals may use to—

clause.text: find reliable and trustworthy information sources; and
identify how information can be manipulated for the consumer; and

subparagraph.text: encourage habits that support the motivation to learn based on verifiably true facts when engaging with information sources; and

paragraph.text: improve information and media literacy and resilience to misinformation and disinformation among students attending elementary schools, secondary schools, institutions of higher education, and adult education institutions.

subsection.text: In carrying out the duties under subsection (b), the Commission shall actively consult with experts in media and information literacy and experts in misinformation and disinformation, State and local educational agencies, and State higher education agencies as determined appropriate by the Commission.
The Commission may conduct periodic studies regarding the status of information and media literacy and educational resources in the United States, as the Commission determines appropriate.
The Commission may take such steps as are appropriate to support the development of information and media literacy and education materials in languages other than English.
The Commission shall be composed of the following members:

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Education, or the Secretary’s designee.
The Director of the Institute of Museum and Library Sciences, or the Director’s designee.
The Chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, or the Chair’s designee.
The Chair of the Federal Trade Commission, or the Chair’s designee.
The Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, or the Secretary’s designee.
Not fewer than seven experts, selected by the Secretary of Education, who represent diverse populations in the field of information and media literacy, including experts such as—

subparagraph.text: members of the International Communication Association and Association for Education in Journalism and Mass Communication; and
experts cited in relevant professional journals such as First Monday, Journal of Information Literacy, and Communications in Information Literacy.

subsection.text: Each member of the Commission may designate an alternate if the member is unable to attend a meeting of the Commission. Such alternate shall be an individual who exercises significant decision-making authority in the organization of the member, as determined by the member concerned.
The Secretary of Education or the Secretary’s designee shall serve as the Chairperson of the Commission.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chairperson—

subparagraph.text: not less frequently than once every 4 months during the period of one year following the date of the initial meeting of the Commission under subsection (f);
not less frequently than biannually after the expiration of such period; and
at such other times as the Chairperson determines appropriate to carry out this title.

paragraph.text: All meetings of the Commission shall be open to the public.

subsection.text: A majority of the members of the Commission shall constitute a quorum, but a lesser number of members may hold hearings.
The Commission shall hold its first meeting not later than 60 days after the date of enactment of this Act.
The Commission may hold such hearings, sit and act at such times and places, take such testimony, and receive such evidence as the Commission considers appropriate to carry out this title.
In hearings held under this subsection, the Commission shall consider inviting witnesses from—

paragraph.text: State and local educational agencies and State higher education agencies with expertise in information or media literacy;
recognized information or media literacy experts; and
recognized experts in online hate, disinformation, and misinformation.

subsection.text: Each member of the Commission shall serve without compensation. Members of the Commission who are full-time officers or employees of the United States may not receive additional pay, allowances, or benefits by reason of their service on the Commission.

The members of the Commission shall be allowed travel expenses, including per diem in lieu of subsistence, in accordance with applicable provisions subchapter I of chapter 57 of title 5, United States Code.
Any employee of the Federal Government may be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and such detail shall be without interruption or loss of civil service status or privilege.

section.header: National strategy for information and media literacy and preventing misinformation and disinformation

subsection.text: The Commission shall—

paragraph.text: not later than 18 months after the date of enactment of this Act, develop a national strategy to promote information and media literacy and resilience to misinformation and disinformation among the American public; and
coordinate the efforts of the Federal Government to implement the strategy developed under paragraph (1).

subsection.text: The strategy under subsection (a) shall—

paragraph.text: be developed with the participation of State and local governments (including State higher education agencies), nonprofit organizations, and institutions of higher education;
include strategies for—

subparagraph.text: increasing the general information and media literacy education level of the American public;
enhancing the public’s general understanding of how information platforms operate; and
encouraging members of the public to critically analyze information sources and recognize manipulation, misinformation, and disinformation; and

paragraph.text: include an assessment of existing efforts to promote information and media literacy and education with a particular focus on misinformation and disinformation.

subsection.text: On a periodic basis at times determined appropriate by the Commission, the Commission shall review the national strategy developed under subsection (b) and make such changes and recommendations as it determines necessary.

Not later than 18 months after the date of the first meeting of the Commission, and annually thereafter, the Commission shall submit to the appropriate congressional committees a report on the progress of the Commission in carrying out this title.
Each report required under subsection (a) shall include—

paragraph.text: a copy of the national strategy developed under section 105;
information concerning the implementation of the duties of the Commission;
an assessment of the availability, utilization, and effectiveness of existing information and media literacy and educational materials;
a brief summary of the information and media literacy and education materials and data regarding the dissemination and impact of such materials;
a brief summary of any hearings conducted by the Commission, including a list of witnesses who testified at such hearings;
information about any activities of the Commission planned for the year following the date of the report; and
such other information as the Commission determines appropriate.

section.text: There are authorized to be appropriated such sums as may be necessary to carry out this title.

section.header: Grants to improve the American public’s information and media literacy and resilience to misinformation and disinformation

subsection.text: Beginning after the Commission completes the development of the national strategy under section 105, the Secretary of Education shall carry out a program under which the Secretary awards grants, on a competitive basis, to one or more qualified nonprofit organizations, including institutions of higher education, to develop educational materials, multimedia awareness campaigns, and programming to support information and media literacy and to combat misinformation and disinformation for the greater American public.
The Secretary of Education shall carry out the grant program under this section in a manner that reflects the findings of the Commission with respect to—

paragraph.text: supporting public awareness of information and media literacy;
improving individual information and media literacy skills;
improving how information and media literacy is addressed in educational settings; and
improving the public's resilience to misinformation and disinformation.

subsection.text: In carrying out the program under subsection (a), the Secretary may award grants for the development of educational materials, multimedia awareness campaigns, and programming in languages other than English as the Secretary determines appropriate.
The Secretary shall develop and implement a process to evaluate the effectiveness of the activities carried out with grants under this section.
On an annual basis during each year of the grant program under this section, the Secretary shall submit to the appropriate congressional committees a report on the status of the program.
There are authorized to be appropriated to carry out this section $3,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2022, 2023, and 2024.

section.header: Study and report on information and media literacy among the American public

subsection.text: The Secretary of Education shall conduct a study to evaluate the extent of information and media literacy among the American public.
The study under subsection (a) shall examine the extent of the American public’s knowledge and awareness of—

paragraph.text: how social media content is created;
how members of the public make choices about information as they consume, create, and share it;

how intermediary technologies for search and social sharing use algorithms and personal information to influence the circulation and amplification or suppression of news, information, opinion, and disinformation;
methods to search and evaluate the reliability of information;
how news is gathered and reported and how that process differs from opinion writing and information presented in talk-show formats; and
how disinformation and misinformation are shared and circulated.

subsection.text: Not later than one year after the date of enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Education shall submit to the appropriate congressional committees a report on the findings and conclusions the study conducted under subsection (a), together with—

paragraph.text: recommendations for legislative or administrative action based on such study; and
recommendations for improving information and media literacy and resilience to misinformation and disinformation among the American public.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Education shall conduct an assessment of the effectiveness of the Commission in promoting information and media literacy and education in accordance with title I.

Not later than 3 years after the date of enactment of this Act, the Department of Education shall submit to the appropriate congressional committees a report on the results of the study conducted under subsection (a).
